"The weight of the scientific evidence is clear: On hot days, light-colored roofs can stay more than 50 degrees cooler than dark ones, helping cut energy use, curb greenhouse gas emissions and reduce heat-related illnesses and deaths."

So of course those making dark roofs don't want cities or states adopting cool-roof requirements.

content:
I've finished: Arboreality by Rebecca Campbell

The crazy thing about Arboreality is that for all the pane and loss of the climate apocalypse, it is a hopeful novella.

The loss and tragedy are central to the plot, but adaptation and perseverance are the direction it takes.

Together with a great love of wood and trees and a wonderful violin subplot. This tail of changing people in a changing landscape is a very human story about the history and future of forests.

card.title: Climate, Peace and Security Fact Sheet: Haiti (2025)
card.description: Located on the Atlantic hurricane belt, Haiti is susceptible to earthquakes and is particularly vulnerable to the adverse impacts of climate change due to its geographical location as well as political instability, extreme poverty and gang violence. Rising sea levels, changing precipitation patterns and frequent natural disasters and extreme weather events, such as hurricanes, floods, droughts, landslides and earthquakes, exacerbate the country‚Äôs humanitarian crisis. Flooding during El Ni√±o years worsens existing food insecurity and drives displacement, increasing population pressure on host communities and fuelling social tensions.

card.title: Witnesses or Resources? On Peat, Laboring Bodies, and Imperial Practice
card.description: The Soviet vision of seamless transformation ‚Äì for example, converting peatlands into energy sources and arable land, and people into compliant laborers ‚Äì was largely realized. However, as Jeanna Kolesova reveals, this transformation left behind traces of persistent violence, such as smoldering ‚Äòzombie‚Äô fires that erupt into large-scale wildfires every 10 to 15 years, increased greenhouse gas emissions, and the oral histories of workers injured by relentless physical labor.
card.image_description: The collage is composed of Jeanna Kolesova‚Äôs footage, material from a peat mining company (used with permission), and Soviet archival images from TASS, dated 1943 and 1954.

content:
Massive Attack prove 98% emission reduction possible

[Read on Ethical Revolution]

In August last year Massive Attack staged a ‚Äòproof of concept‚Äô one-day festival in Bristol to show that low carbon festivals are doable. I was lucky enough to attend the event and I wrote an extensive report on it at the time.

The Tyndall Centre for Climate Research has now released the findings from analysing the festival‚Äôs emissions, showing that it produced an incredible 98% decrease in power emissions from comparable shows.

Vegan food, incentives to travel by rail and a fleet of electric vehicles reduced catering and haulage emissions by 89% and 70% respectively.

The report also showed that 5% of attendees opted to fly to the festival and in doing so they generated 64% of the event‚Äôs overall greenhouse gases.

[Via Ethical Revolution]

#Bristol #ClimateAction #ClimateChange #ClimateResearch #ElectricVehicles #festivals #MassiveAttack #music #vegan

Indeed common decency tempers risks.

In organisational emergency, we welcome a saviour. It's very effective because he comes up with a solution.

In ecological catastrophes, there is no saviour because there is no solution. The emergency passed decades ago.
The problem goes much deeper. So we need to be careful that words convey ideas:
- an emergency calls for a solution ;
- tragedy requires a different relationship (to everything)

content:
The graph speaks for itself

This graph by Zeke Hausfather (for details) has been popping up a lot recently. It shows monthly global mean temperatures from the Berkeley Earth dataset relative to an 1850-1900 baseline (observations, red line). Behind it we see the CMIP6 ‚ÄúModel Mean‚Äù (black) and the Model 5th-95th Percentile (blue shading).

Most prominently it appeared in the Bluesky feed of Michael Mann, eventually prompting this utterance:

It‚Äôs interesting in so much as you can look at that graph and say (a) I do not know if models and obs are consistent based on this graph and (b) it shows monthly means so doesn‚Äôt tell me anything about acceleration, dramatic or otherwise.

First, we have the big question, what does it mean for observations to be ‚Äúconsistent with models‚Äù (or not)? In general, the idea of consistency is that the red line might have been generated by one of the models (or more generally by a process that‚Äôs similar to the same one that generated by the models, or‚Ä¶ there are variations on this). It‚Äôs unlikely that a random model simulation would look exactly like the real world, so the comparison is often done probabilistically: we want to know if the real world looks like the modelled worlds in some particular way.

For any month in the graph shown above, the black line shows the average across all the model simulations1 and the blue shaded area shows the 5th and 95th percentile across all the model runs. One way to calculate that is to get all the model values for the global mean for that month, sort them into ascending order, chop off the bottom 5% and top 5% and then plot the range of what‚Äôs left. There are other ways.

One meaning of consistency might be that the red line does not stray outside of the blue shaded area very often. How often is very often? It‚Äôs hard to say and partly depends on what you think the blue range represents. If it was a probability distribution from which monthly values were drawn then we could calculate how likely a give observed monthly value was, but that doesn‚Äôt really tell us much. Even if the probability was very small, it could just be that something really unusual happened. The blue shaded area is not a probability distribution though, it‚Äôs just a grab bag of models run varying number of times.

We also need to think about what ‚Äúoften‚Äù might mean when I say ‚Äúthe red line does not stray outside of the blue shaded area very often‚Äù because this brings in the notion of time. We‚Äôre not just making one comparison here, we‚Äôre making lots in the same graph. The upper and lower ends of the model distribution are calculated separately for each time step so they don‚Äôt preserve any useful information about how one month is related to the next and this is a big problem if we want to say anything more general about consistency and about trends.

The observations (red line) move up and down within the blue range, but they do so in a characteristic way. We can see little peaks and dips in the data. Sometimes the observations run above the black line for a while, and sometimes below. In fact, it looks nothing like the black line in which all the model simulations have been averaged together. The effect of that averaging is to smudge out the kinds of the variations you see in the real world and which are in the models. The blue shaded area tells us something about the size of the variations and different rates of long-term warming (we‚Äôll come back to this though), but that‚Äôs all.

I made the schematic shown below sometime ago to illustrate the point. If all we have is the black line and blue shaded area like in panel (a) then we don‚Äôt know if it represents data that look like something from panels (b), (c) or (d). Panel (b) is more like what we see in the real world, but not exactly; it‚Äôs a bit too ‚Äúnoisy‚Äù. (c) is the case where each model run looks exactly the same except they‚Äôre all offset a bit from each other. Panel (d) shows longer term variations. We see something like a mix of (b) and (d) in the real world. If all we have is the blue shaded area, we can‚Äôt say anything much more exciting than the individual monthly values are ‚Äúnot inconsistent with‚Äù the individual monthly values from the models. That‚Äôs a weaker claim than the more positive ‚Äúconsistent with‚Äù. It might still be that all the models look like (d) but the real world looks like (b). In that case we might say that the models are inconsistent with the observations, but we can‚Äôt tell that just by looking at Zeke‚Äôs graph.

The same applies when we ask whether changes in temperature are unusual or not, ‚Äúdramatic‚Äù or not. Zeke‚Äôs graph doesn‚Äôt show trends directly. The viewer has to eyeball them, which is never a good way to do any kind of calculation. We also have nothing to compare the eyeballed trends to. As I said already, there‚Äôs no temporal information from the models that‚Äôs comparable to what we see in the observations. It‚Äôs all been averaged out. It‚Äôs also hard to compare different parts of the observations to each other because doing so requires that we compare two eyeballed estimates. Let‚Äôs not do that.

If you want to compare trends, you should make a graph showing trends. Indeed, we can make graphs showing a wide range of different metrics by which specific comparisons might be made. We still need to be careful though and be very clear about what it is exactly we are comparing and what we want to get out of the comparison.

The blue shaded area is made from lots of different models, each run one or more times. In making the comparison, we are comparing two things. One is the real world which is warming at some particular (but sadly unknown) rate in response to things like greenhouse gases, volcanoes and other factors, modified from one point to the next by internal variability ‚Äì El Nino, La Nina and other natural phenomena ‚Äì plus some measurement error. We are comparing that to a range of models each of which warms at a different rate in response to things like greenhouse gases, volcanoes and other factors (which may differ from those in the real world), modified from one point to the next by internal variability (which may or may not look like the internal variability in the real world). In making the comparison ‚Äì even the simplified month by month comparison ‚Äì we are rolling a lot of different things in together.

If the forcing factors in the real world and models ‚Äì the things like greenhouse gases, human caused aerosols, volcanoes ‚Äì aren‚Äôt the same we might be able to say there is an inconsistency even before we run the models. If the inputs to the model are wrong, then there‚Äôs no reason the output should be right. Historically, they‚Äôre probably not too different, but at some point, the models shift from using historical observation-based estimates of the forcing factors to projected values that might diverge from what then happened in the real world. Part of the argument for an acceleration in observed warming is that the forcing factors are different from the projections ‚Äì fewer anthropogenic aerosols recently, for example ‚Äì so there could be an acceleration in the real world that‚Äôs not in the models at all, without the real world ever leaving the blue shaded envelope.

If the forcings were right in the models we might see the same acceleration (allowing for internal variability) in the models, maybe even in the model mean. But if the forcings are wrong ‚Äì and probably they are ‚Äì then what is ‚Äúconsistency‚Äù telling us? Consistency of the real world on some metric that is a couple of steps from the metric of actual interest, with a set of models that don‚Äôt actually model the phenomenon we are making claims about is‚Ä¶ well, uninformative.

Another aspect of this is why we are asking whether observations and models are consistent. Usually we‚Äôre doing this because what we actually care about is the future. In the case of an acceleration of warming possibly related to an unanticipated change in forcing, then the question is, how should we modify our expectations of future change. There are a whole extra set of questions wrapped up in that and we have to maybe flip the question on its head. Not, are the obs consistent with the models, but which models are consistent with the observations (and therefore a plausible basis for projecting temperatures into the future) or, more generally, how can we use observations and models to generate plausible predictions and projections for the future.

Even assuming all the forcing factors are right, we can ask what should the real world look like? Should it look an individual model simulation. We could argue that in a line up, the real world ought to be indistinguishable from the range of models in some sense, something like this:

Spot the real world.

Maybe the different heights of the lego figures correspond to different rates of warming with all else being equal and we might select models that have a similar historical rate of warming, or weight them depending on how close they are to observations.

Alternatively, we can have variations on this, for example, we might assume that the model simulations might look sort of like the real world, but that they‚Äôre all different in some particular, but important, way, like this:

In this sense, observations and models might look inconsistent in the graph, but we learn something useful from the comparison nonetheless because we expected the inconsistency and factored it into our analysis, we just have to be more cautious in saying what it is we learned.

Caution is good in general. ‚ÄúConsistent with‚Äù or, more usually, ‚Äúnot inconsistent with‚Äù can both be relatively weak claims. We could shade the whole white area of Zeke‚Äôs graph blue, draw a straight black line through the middle of it, and claim that the real world is consistent with that. It doesn‚Äôt tell us anything useful though.

In particular, when we are assessing a claim such as ‚Äúthere has been a recent acceleration in warming in the real world‚Äù we need to understand more fully what that means ‚Äì what caused the acceleration, perhaps, how we measure an acceleration etc. ‚Äì so that we can choose appropriate metrics and graphs that can help us to understand the situation better. Even then, eyeballing a metric and graph chosen specifically to answer a questions is short of what a thorough analysis entails even for a very specific claim.

Even if the models and observations are inconsistent in some particular sense, it doesn‚Äôt mean there‚Äôs not something more that can be learned from the situation. There is a very well known saying from a chap called Box:

‚ÄúAll models are wrong but some are useful‚Äù

But to loop all this back to the title of the post, while the graph might, indeed ‚Äúspeak for itself‚Äù what it says is often very limited. We should be very careful about putting words in its mouth, or indeed misquoting it. There is a tendency in online discussions to assume that a graph is the whole of an argument. It‚Äôs very rarely the case, if it ever is at all. A graph is just a way of presenting a particular aspect of the data. It can form a part of an argument, but shouldn‚Äôt be mistaken for the whole thing. In any reasonably complex discussion, a graph might be interpretable in many different ways. We should be very wary of saying there is only the one.

  1. I‚Äôm not sure exactly how Zeke calculated it. ‚Ü©Ô∏é

#climateChange #science
